awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Predictive Simulations of Complex Kinetic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to build an integrated program of research and education focused on advances in predictive simulations of complex kinetic systems. Such systems are comprised of a large number of particles in random motion and are best described by the Boltzmann and related kinetic equations. In practical applications, there are many sources of uncertainties that can arise in kinetic systems: imprecise measurements for initial and boundary conditions, incomplete knowledge of the fundamental interaction mechanism between particles, and so on. Understanding the impact of these uncertainties is critical to the simulations of the complex kinetic systems, and will allow scientists and engineers to obtain more reliable predictions and perform better risk assessment. Due to the unique challenges arising in kinetic equations, such as multiple scales, high dimensionality, and positivity, very few existing generic uncertainty quantification (UQ) algorithms can be applied directly. To bridge this gap, the research objective of this project is to develop highly efficient stochastic and multiscale numerical methods for Boltzmann-like kinetic equations. A parallel educational objective is to create innovative opportunities for students at all levels to improve science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education and promote career interest in these disciplines, especially among female students. 

Specifically, we will pursue four research and educational aims: 1) develop stochastic asymptotic-preserving methods for multiscale kinetic equations; 2) construct high performance stochastic algorithms for the Boltzmann collision operator; 3) design physics-preserving UQ algorithms for kinetic systems; and 4) create education and outreach activities for students through undergraduate STEM classroom innovation; graduate curriculum development in kinetic theory; graduate and undergraduate mentoring; and organizing an after-school math research program for high school girls and family math/science nights at middle and elementary schools.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The overall objective of this project is to develop highly efficient multiscale numerical methods for conducting uncertainty quantification (UQ) of the Boltzmann equation and related kinetic models. Over the past few years, the PI and students/collaborators have developed a series of numerical methods for kinetic equations, including stochastic Galerkin methods, multilevel Monte Carlo methods, fast spectral methods for collision operators, and structure-preserving (such as asymptotic-preserving (AP), positivity-preserving, and energy dissipative) methods. The PI was also invited to write a few survey papers on UQ for kinetic equations, AP schemes for multiscale hyperbolic and kinetic equations, and Fourier spectral methods for nonlinear Boltzmann equations. The scientific achievements in all these directions greatly enhance our understanding of complex kinetic systems. To give one concrete example, the figure on the right shows the results of a shock tube problem with uncertainty in the location of the shock interface, obtained using our proposed AP stochastic Galerkin (sG) method. The method performs reasonably well under a coarse mesh. Note that for this problem the conventional sG method fails even at the first time step.

Three graduate students, who all successfully defended their theses in 2021, were partially supported by the grant during their time at Purdue University. Additionally, two graduate students at the University of Washington received partial support from the grant during 2021-2023. The grant also facilitated the PI's extended travel to Europe for collaborative research, spanning one month in 2019. The visit not only proved scientifically beneficial, initiating several research collaborations, but also significantly enhanced the PI's visibility in the early stages of her career development. In fact, it partly led to the six-month scientific program on kinetic theory that the PI co-organized at the Isaac Newton Institute, University of Cambridge, in 2022.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2023
Modified by: Jingwei Hu

Image
  • Mean and standard deviation of the density profile in a shock tube problem with uncertainty in the location of the shock interface. Solid line: reference solution; other legends: solutions obtained by our proposed AP stochastic Galerkin method with different spatial resolution.
    Jingwei Hu
    Copyrighted
    Jingwei Hu
    UQ for Boltzmann
